comments.commentBody: sorry, forget the comma
You did not. The comma after "Tales" is inappropriate.
I'm not an expert but I don't think you need a comma after the word "that". Also, "correctly" should be "correct".

I was taught that a comma always follows however. However, there are exceptions.

As for the semicolon, Edgar Allan Poe used them frequently. I can recall reading a paragraph in one of his Gothic Tales, that was composed with all semicolons in place of commas.

I hope I got my punctuations correctly here.

It is not reckless speculation to invest in derivatives. It is an investment strategy that is normally used as a hedge against other losses. When a farmer sells on the futures market, that is a derivative that someone else is buying. Companies buy futures in foreign money markets to hedge against changes in value where they trade. But it does involve a higher risk as it has high leverage. You can not group all banks into the same kind of banking business. JP Morgan was an investment bank, that is its culture. It has to be separated from Chase.They rescued Chase from imminent collapse, but the two must be kept separate.

What happened to those stodgy banks? they were allowed to participate in the investment market with the repeal of the Glass-Stegal Act. Banks have always tried to increase shareholder value, it is nothing new, but after 1933 the commercial banks were not allowed to act as investment banks. That is to finance new issues, or finance commercial bonds. They were allowed to make loans and to invest in investment grade securities and bonds.

Shareholders are becoming less important as their votes are appropriated by interests within the banks and bank share holding community. Unless someone, or some  group "inside" will use a majority of voting rights, there will be no change and you can be sure that the bank officers control all the voting rights they need.No one goes into these meetings unless they have fully loaded guns or lawyers or both.
That won't work because the bankers will still take foolish risks,rake in huge salaries and when a crisis comes they will get help from the government

What I find puzzling about the banks' reluctance to more transparency of the derivatives market, is that losses such as the ones perpetrated by Chase are huge and could have been much worse. As Paul Krugman notes, Chase admitted to $2 billion initially but that figure could approach $5 billion. Over the past month, Chase stock has declined 20% relative to the S & P 500. I doubt shareholders are happy.

How is reckless speculation on derivatives, which are essentially options, beneficial to share holders? What happened to the days when banks were thought of as stodgy and conservative. Now comes the young breed intent on a quick buck and perhaps hugely inflated salaries and egos?

Let all banks sign an agreement that in the future, they recognize that the U.S. Treasury and U.S. taxpayers will not participate in their folly, nor to subsidize or prop them up when their comeuppance arrives yet once again.

Huh? How many more golds does USA have to win before Colangelo "gets it"?

USA has proven that FIBA tournaments require athletic depth, athletic depth, and more athletic depth. in the 2008 Olympics and 2010 Worlds, savvy play was neutralized by American athleticism, not the other way around.
Some kid is probably putting code into a program that will make Facebook a dinosaur before the end of 2012.

Facebook was, is and will likely turn out to be a suboptimal business investment.

The financial investors in Facebook were looking for a liquidity event and they got one and cashed out.

Zuckerberg himself may or may not care about the value of his shareholding and frankly no investor should care about what he thinks of them because he has made it clear that he does not give a hoot about them

I do believe that Facebook employees do and will care about the stock price performance. And on that score Facebook has a major disaster on it hands.

And folks that is what matters. If employees do not have monetary incentive at Facebook , at best they will be demotivated and at worst they will leave the company.

Furthermore, it is unclear that advertisers will throw money at Facebook when the benefits of advertising on Facebook are pretty unclear and likely to be irrelevant.
Facebook has yet to enunciate a plan for monetizing mobile and it is unlikely that they will ever be able to monetize mobile. I totally refute any argument that suggests that mobile is an opportunity because to me it represents an abject failure on the part of FB.

Maybe FB is the best investment in the world. However,at current valuations, I suspect that Facebook has a lot more downside risk than upside potential.

"Oh wait, Prust a hard working, clean player..."

You watching the same NHL as the rest of us?

It may be that Prust tried to elbow Volchenkov in the back and not the head, but, Prust obviously through an elbow. I am a long time Ranger fan, and although you are correct that Shannahan has not been consistent, I believe that he got it right on this one.

Only one on this list, methinks, merits the Olympics: Cricket. It's out of sight and mind in the U.S. but it's HUGE elsewhere in the world.

I have two friends, both doctors, one from India, the other from Pakistan (they get along very well) who have a passion for Cricket, specially when their home countries play each other, that is phenomenal. It's the same everywhere it's played.

I'd like to see some MLB players take it up (ok, those who didn't make a team) and then take on the world's best! It would have to be the Twenty20 format, but you better believe there'd be interest. Cricket belongs.

Oh, and maybe tug-of-war.
EWES done it again, 'OwieML!

Leapy, I see what you mean. He's b~a~a~a~ck!

Welcome back, Pastor Munster.
Closing in on the record...

Egregious error in the clue for 35D, it wasn't Macbeth, who uttered "AVAUNT to be alone and quit my sight!" it was Greta Garbo...C'mon, Will, how could you not see that?

WHH
Who can afford to live in NYC?  Why, Mr. Bloomberg and his billionaire friends, that's who!  The rest of us count for nothing, as Mr. Bloomberg has made quite clear.

walk, ride a bicycle, take the subway, hop a bus

forget the cab unless the situation is dire.

You're right: you don't understand! I have an 87-year-old neighbor with emphysema, and who has many medical appointments at various Manhattan hospitals. This neighbor is not able to climb the subway stairs, and must travel with a home-care aide.

So, do you think my neighbor ought to buy a car, hire a limo, ride a bike, or just get elected mayor so that getting around Manhattan will never be an issue?

@ask123, yes, there IS a problem with cell phone use by the cab driver: it is illegal, plain & simple. And if you think the passenger does not know the driver's on the phone, you must think we all fell off the turnip truck yesterday.

My solution is this: I tell cab drivers "You should not be on the phone and you know it. Please get off the phone." Those who get off the phone, no problem. For those who don't get off the phone, I don't tip them and I tell them that I am not tipping because they continued to talk on their phone.

However, if the TLC actually cared about enforcing this rule, I ought not have to go through any of that!

Where have you been? The price of healthcare has gone up more than 20% in the last five years, not to mention the price of CEO's and hedge fund managers.  But the price of politicians is what's really galling,

Oh, come on people. People write this all the time: "In Europe, something, something, something."

Need this be pointed out, Europe is a very big place. Are we talking about Paris? London? Bratislava? Subotica? Barcelona? Rome? Prague? Budapest? Kiev? Munich? Warsaw? Moscow? Lisbon? Belfast? Where?

Making a monolithic statement about Europe is as dumb as saying that rents are high in the US and not noting if you're talking about New York or Ames, Iowa.
Funny, I was just thinking that about Alaska.

What's the big deal? I don't think I've taken a cab in years. They're already so outrageously priced, they're off limits.
Oh, and their fares haven't risen since 2006? Well, my earnings haven't risen since 2000! Care to give me a raise??

we are already in depression only our Mayor Billionburg will not accept this fact. I think the real practical solution is that CITY MUST stop collecting MTA TAX from cab drivers and there is no need for hike. Therefore, more passengers for cab drivers. win-win situation for everyone.
I object to BBQ smoke!   Grilling dead animals is not my idea of a good odor, nor is smoke from charcoal.
I don't own and drive a car.  Do you feel guilty about the noxious carbon fumes you put in the air?

in the meantime people will continue to have their lives blighted by the disgusting and carcinogenic fumes. And then what? Those of us unfortunate enough to live in buildings with ignorant leadership that decide to throw open their doors to smokers can all pick up and move elsewhere? Can you imagine the mass migration? The best solution right now is electronic cigarettes.

I think the free market will work here.  Many buildings will go smoke-free.  But others will go smoke-friendly because there will be a demand for it.  People will sort themselves out between these buildings based on their smoking preference.  And in the end, everyone will be happier.
Sounds like a hauntingly familiar scenario. Perhaps that's what it's come down to.

...or better yet, send them to a housing project in Manhattan.  That would be better punishment since Manhattan is such a boring place now filled with nothing but rich people, clueless transplants, chain stores, etc.  Queens is colorful and full of real NYers and amazing ethnic restaurants of every stripe and so sending the smokers there would not be as much punishment as banishing them to the overpriced island of Manhattan.

I have an idea, which might be the solution to this murky mess. Evict every single smoker and shuttle them to a housing project in Queens; this will soon evolve in the press as the "smokers ghetto." They will each recieive a one month supply of nicotine patches. If they still remain obdurate in their insistence that they have
a constutional right and are being persecuted by the health fascists, they should then be rounded up and taken to the Freight yards beneath Queens Plaza and force them into box cars that will take them to an undisclosed location in Herkimer valley where they will disembark and be taken to the into the bowels of an old, unused instutional building. A bald, brutish aryan looking officer is generously passing out cigarettes and as he does he smiles diabolically while proclaiming, "Smok'em will you got em'" 'Just think, today yo will have smoked the the lastt cigarette.

To portray companies like Bain as saviors of failing companies is ludicrous.  Bain is not in business to save companies.  On the contrary, they have destroyed many good companies.  They are in business for one and only one reason--to make as much money for themselves as fast as they can regardless of the consequences.

i am glad to see charles hurwitz  mentioned. his company was called maxxam. it was tragic the way he took a forest products company with a sustainable model of forest management and sped up the logging program to pay his debt. as a footnote, this is what brought 100s of "tree huggers" to northern CA in the late 70s to protect and protest this action and energized environmental organizations in the process.

Cathy,you are way beyond boundaries even to grasp what DEMOCRATES want for USA. We do love & support capitalism if it have successfully built wealth for nation as a whole. But facts do not support your faulty narratives as phony capitalism since last 3+decades have thrown US into ditch of DEFICITS instead any surplus. Clinton did tried to balance the budget with some futurastic surplus but your buddy Bush started using it by giving tax bracks claiming he won it as political equity by winning election(?)in 2000. Did he win eigther election of 2000 or 2004 rightfully?The answer is big NO.
That's how DEMOCRATES & GOPTPers work for capitalism,one loves true path to walk on while other choose wrong path for quick,unsustainable & unrealistic phony capitalistic way like junk bond promotters who buys them,sucks the juice & hand over others for losses & bankrupcies.

If Mr. Brooks is now trying to justify the private equity method of business. The record is in fact dismal.Start with RJR Nabisco, the raiding of pension funds, the destruction of stockholders retirement dividend income. Then Pacific Lumber a leveraged buyout by Charles Hurwitz, that counted on cutting down all the company's lumber in order to get a quick payback.

We have Michael Millkiken, who bought the junk bonds of companies, took them over in order to cash them out. Look at the records of Black Rock, and all these other private equity firms that Brooks so admires.

Their mode of operation is to buy a distressed firm, cut expenses to the bare minimum, which means laying off as many employees as possible, load them up with debt, pay themselves large bonuses for rescuing these firms, then sell them back to the public using IPOs, which gives them an even bigger payday. The majority of these firms are in bankruptcy within two years.

Occasionally a company survives and the equity firm tells the public what a great job they are doing.

Bain Capital is no different. They made a great deal of money from the bankruptcy of that steel mill. This is not change Brooks, this is not capitalism, this is scavenging.
We seem to have forgotten the meaning of Capitalism. Capitalism is the accumulation and ownership of the means of production. Andrew Carnegie was a Capitalist. Bain Capital is an accumulator of money, not a creator of Capital and value.

Ravi was convicted of a bias crime, not a hate crime.
Unlike the example above Ravi did not tape anyone naked or doing anything sexually explict.

Here's hoping the Rangers' luck is finally running out. But I'm sure the insufferable Tortortella will start whining again about some manufactured missed call and the refs will end up giving them the advantage in game 5 at home.

Len, check the standings again: Ottawa was seeded 8th, so there's no way they were the only representative from their division. Boston finished 1st in the Northeast and was seeded 2nd. Then they too lost in the 1st round.

Whine, whine, whine, Ranger fans...you take after your coach, the biggest whiner in pro sports. I don't have much faith in old man Brodeur and the faceless Devils, but if they happen to win this series, I will become a Devils fan for life!
